title: Manchester Arndale stabbings: Police praise public who helped treat victims after attack
text:

Police have praised members of the public who helped emergency services treat injured victims following an attack at Manchester's Ardnale Shopping Centre yesterday.

Witnesses said a knifeman screamed “I’m going to f*** you up” before carrying out random attacks - stabbing three people.

The stabbings happened at around 11.15am yesterday and the whole area was cordoned off.

Three people - 19-year-old Chloe McGurk from Belfast, who was visiting Manchester with friends for a 'girly weekend', another 19-year-old woman and a man in his 50s - were stabbed before being taken to hospital.

The force tweeted earlier this afternoon: "A number of members of the public assisted emergency services treating the injured victims at the #Arndale yesterday and we want to publically thank them for their assistance. We want to continue to urge people with information to contact police on 0161 856 0394."

The Arndale shopping centre is open as usual today but there is an increased police presence around the city.

A 40-year-old man has been arrested on suspicion of terrorism offences following the incident.

Forensic spent around five hours searching the house of the alleged attacker.

Neighbours on Rochdale Road told the Manchester Evening News they immediately recognised the suspect when footage of his arrest by armed officers began circulating on social media.

This morning police confirmed a search had been carried out at an undisclosed location in Manchester where the suspected attacker had previously lived.

He's thought to have lived at the property for about 12 months.

The investigation is now being led by counter terrorism police.

(Image: Facebook)

Officers are trying to establish if the man had any political, religious or ideological motivation for the attack.

The man's mental health is also being closely considered as a factor in the attack.

After being arrested on suspicion of terrorism offences he was detained under the Mental Health Act.

(Image: MEN MEDIA)

A woman in her 40s was not stabbed, but was assessed by paramedics, and another woman received a 'superficial knife injury' in the attack.

This morning Assistant Chief Constable Russ Jackson said: "The investigation will be continued by counter terrorism officers and an open mind is being kept in relation to any motive and of course the man is considered unfit to be kept in custody and has now been transferred to mental health detention."

(Image: PA)

Greater Manchester Mayor Andy Burnham told the Manchester Evening News he wished the victims a 'speedy recovery' and said he was prepared to authorise greater use of police stop and search powers in a bid to tackle knife crime.

He said: "The investigation is ongoing but it appears to be an isolated incident.

"We are not unique. These things are happening around the world and we are living in more volatile time.

"Mental health is a growing concern not just for our society but everywhere.

"A lot of people come here for a lot of different reasons, it's a great city. Because of that, it brings extra pressure. It is very much business as usual today and great to see everyone returning.

"We are living in difficult times and it probably does mean we need to look out for each other and be extra vigilant, but for people coming to the city it's a case of recognising we are not immune to the times we are living in.

"This is a city that has a strong civic response and we will do everything to keep people safe here."
description: Three people were stabbed in the attack at Manchester's Arndale Shopping Centre on Friday
